Red Flags For Anti-Aging Products

Click each card to to review the red flags and solutions

Are the claims too good to be true (e.g. "a fountain of youth in a bottle")?

If the claims promise fast, dramatic results without any scientific evidence to support them, they’re likely to be untrue. Legitimate advertisements are typically required to disclose any significant risks associated with the drug.

Are the researchers mentioned on the website real individuals?

Look up the names of the researchers and verify their credentials using professional networks like LinkedIn or academic publications. If you can’t find any information about them, it’s likely that these profiles are fabricated.

Are the customer testimonials authentic and reliable?

Be wary of vague or exaggerated claims in product testimonials, as these may indicate the reviews are fake. Positive reviews can be easily fabricated, so always be skeptical of testimonials.
